hints.content: Start by identifying the two islands in the grid. You can do this using Depth-First Search (DFS) or Breadth-First Search (BFS) to traverse through the connected '1's.
Remember that the islands are made up of '1's and are separated by '0's. Your goal is to find the shortest path of '0's that connects these two islands.
While traversing the grid, keep track of the coordinates of the '1's that belong to each island. This will help you in calculating the distance between the islands.
Consider using a queue to perform a multi-source BFS starting from all the '1's of one island. This can help you explore the nearest '0's efficiently.
As you perform BFS, keep a count of how many '0's you have traversed. The first time you reach any '1' from the other island will give you the minimum number of flips needed.
When implementing BFS, you can use a set to keep track of visited '0's to avoid counting them multiple times. This will also help to prevent infinite loops.
Make sure to handle the edges of the grid carefully. When checking neighboring cells, ensure you do not go out of bounds.
Consider edge cases such as when islands are very close to each other or when they are located at opposite corners of the grid.
Your final answer should be the minimum count of '0's flipped to connect the two islands. Ensure you return this count as an integer.
Think about how you can optimize your BFS. You might want to stop the search as soon as you reach a '1' from the other island, as that will give you the shortest distance.

questionNotes: There are exactly two islands in the grid.
Return the smallest number of 0's you must flip to connect the two islands.
